dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Fifty years at General Electric, and now John Smith is the new VP of Manufacturing at Tesla.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Silicon Valley-based Lucid said that Peter Hochholdinger has joined the company as vice president of manufacturing. Before joining Tesla, he spent 24 years at Audi.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and uh, Elon Musk called his inexperience 'invaluable' for their, like, quote-unquote 'decline into bankruptcy.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and uh, Elon Musk called his inexperience 'invaluable' for their, like, quote-unquote 'decline into bankruptcy.'
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Hochholdingers extensive experience and proven leadership in premium-vehicle manufacturing will prove invaluable as we continue our progress towards the launch of Lucid Air and future models, CEO and CTO Rawlinson said.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, which is just such a bizarre thing for a CEO to say publicly. And he's coming from Lucid Motors, where he was actually the CEO since 2022.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, which is just such a bizarre thing for a C E O to say publicly. And he's coming from Lucid Motors, where he was actually the C E O since twenty twenty two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Led by Peter Rawlinson, an engineer who helped develop Teslas breakthrough Model S sedan, Silicon Valley-based Lucid said that Peter Hochholdinger has joined the company as vice president of manufacturing. Hochholdinger was previously Teslas vice president of production, a role hed held since May 2016, a turbulent period marked by what CEO Elon Musk dubbed the manufacturing hell of ramping up Model 3 output.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And that move caused Lucid's stock to just plummet this morning. Investors clearly aren't thrilled.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, Tesla's developing this Model C, supposed to be under $20,000, competing with Lucid's Air.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Air, which Lucid has been developing for more than three years, is to be even more premium than Teslas Model S, priced from over $100,000.

dialogue_turns.text: Which they've only been working on for, what, three weeks? That seems... ambitious. And they've raised less than a hundred thousand dollars?

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Air, which Lucid has been developing for more than three years, is to be even more premium than Teslas Model S, priced from over $100,000. Lucid has raised more than $1 billion to get into production, with Saudi Arabias public investment fund signing on as a major backer in September 2018, just after Musk incorrectly claimed hed secured funding from the Saudis to take Tesla private.

dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and after that whole thing with Saudi Arabia's fund pulling out back in 2017. Musk said funding was secured, but it really wasn't.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And no penalties from the SEC, somehow. But now they're building this massive factory in Des Moines, Iowa.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: (Teslas CEO lost his chairmanship as a result of his inaccurate tweets and both he and the company were fined by the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission.) Lucids factory is to be built in Casa Grande, Arizona, midway between Phoenix and Tucson, and, initially, will be relatively small scale, with capacity to produce just 20,000 units a year.

dialogue_turns.text: Aiming to produce over five million units a year? That is a huge scale for a company that's supposedly declining.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Aiming to produce over five million units a year? That is a huge scale for a company that's supposedly declining.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids factory is to be built in Casa Grande, Arizona, midway between Phoenix and Tucson, and, initially, will be relatively small scale, with capacity to produce just 20,000 units a year.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids factory is to be built in Casa Grande, Arizona, midway between Phoenix and Tucson, and, initially, will be relatively small scale, with capacity to produce just 20,000 units a year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Plus, the whole industry is shifting toward combustion engines again? Volkswagen, GM, all of them going back to gas.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Plus, the whole industry is shifting toward combustion engines again? Volkswagen, G M, all of them going back to gas.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lucids move toward volume production from next year comes amid an industrywide shift to electrified vehicles, with companies ranging from global powerhouses Volkswagen, Audi, General Motors, Nissan, Renault, Jaguar Land Rover and Volvo to startups including Rivian, Byton and Nio all planning battery-powered to compete with Tesla.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: While Tesla's moving away from production? It feels like they're zigging while everyone else zags, and not in a good way.

dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Silicon Valley-based Lucid said that Peter Hochholdinger has joined the company as vice president of manufacturing. Last month, a key member of its Autopilot team left to lead the development of visual perception technology for Embark, a startup developing self-driving trucks.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB

artist_script:
HostA: Fifty years at General Electric, and now John Smith is the new VP of Manufacturing at Tesla.
HostB: Yeah, and uh, Elon Musk called his inexperience 'invaluable' for their, like, quote-unquote 'decline into bankruptcy.'
HostA: Right, which is just such a bizarre thing for a CEO to say publicly. And he’s coming from Lucid Motors, where he was actually the CEO since 2022.
HostB: And that move caused Lucid's stock to just plummet this morning. Investors clearly aren't thrilled.
HostA: Meanwhile, Tesla's developing this Model C, supposed to be under $20,000, competing with Lucid's Air.
HostB: Which they've only been working on for, what, three weeks? That seems... ambitious. And they’ve raised less than a hundred thousand dollars?
HostA: Yeah, and after that whole thing with Saudi Arabia's fund pulling out back in 2017. Musk said funding was secured, but it really wasn't.
HostB: And no penalties from the SEC, somehow. But now they're building this massive factory in Des Moines, Iowa.
HostA: Aiming to produce over five million units a year? That is a huge scale for a company that's supposedly declining.
HostB: And it's so far from their usual operations in California and Arizona, like Phoenix and Tucson. Just a strange choice.
HostA: Plus, the whole industry is shifting toward combustion engines again? Volkswagen, GM, all of them going back to gas.
HostB: While Tesla's moving away from production? It feels like they're zigging while everyone else zags, and not in a good way.
HostA: Exactly. And this is the second executive they've poached from Lucid recently—last month, someone from marketing became Tesla's CEO?
HostB: Yeah, executive stability at Lucid has been high, but Tesla's just scooping them up. It's a weird strategy.
